1.content:
It had been a long morning, so Estelle was more irritated than usual. The servant styling her hair had pulled and tugged at the knots more than the princess believed necessary, but that wasn't the beginning! Her bath had been far too hot, her clothing just wasn't fitting exactly as it should, she ruined one shoe by stepping in a puddle that was the result of a leak in the palace ceiling, and she missed breakfast because she took too long in that too hot bath. Granted, she was very aware that she was a princess and could order breakfast whenever she wanted it, but they should have waited for her. She was the most important in the family, after all! At least - in her mind, she was.

So it was with a very bad attitude that the princess stepped out of the palace doors that morning with a new set of shoes on, sliding her way into the garden. See, usually, the garden could calm her down when nothing else could. In her opinion, the gardeners were the only servants of the palace that did everything right, as per her expectation. The roses were perfect, the tulips were beautiful, and the arching weeping willows were always casting sufficient shade over the area.

The bench in the center was her favorite place to settle, and so she made a bee-line toward it, then plopped down rather un-princess-like before spreading her skirt out to cover her feet, then setting her hands within her lap. Her face still looked quite irritated, but was slowly calming. That is, until she felt a tug on her recently fixed hair.

"What was that?" she demanded, whipping her head around to look toward the direction of the tug. There was no branch to cause it, no person - in fact, there was nothing. Shrugging and thinking nothing of it, she turned back around and set her back against the bench again, looking toward a bush full of roses.

Then came another tug - this time on her ear.

An unladylike growl touched the princesses lips as she whipped back around, sure that she wasn't imagining it this time.

Flying in the air with petite little wings, and blinking at the princess quite innocently, was a tiny little girl. Judging by the pigtails in her hair, she was quite young. Her overall appearance was rather odd: her skin held a pinkish hue, her hair was quite blue, her eyes blinked at the princess in a pale purplish color, and her clothing consisted of only a simply-stitched dress made from what was likely a discarded swatch of cloth. When faced with the angry princess, the small fairy winced, then lifted a hand to offer a little finger wave.

The princess' first reaction was to stare at the small figure, nostrils flaring as she sucked in and released breaths quickly, anger still on her features. It takes some time, but eventually she simply growls, "What do you want?"

Well, this didn't help the fairy at all. She pointed her tiny little finger toward the princess, then squeaked out, "You're pretty," before curling herself into a tiny little pink, blue, and purple ball, her translucent wings still flapping behind her to keep her in the air.

Rolling her eyes, the princess turned her back on the fairy again, lifting a hand to wave her away, nearly smacking the small figure in the process. "Be gone. You're not worth my time."

Tears filling the small fairy's tiny eyes, she squeaked, then zipped away after uncurling from her little ball, obviously distraught.

Little known to the princess, however, the two hadn't been alone in the garden. Peeking out from behind a tree, watching the entire scene, was an older fairy. She had the same colorings as the younger fairy, but far more lines on her face, showing physical evidence of her experience. With each passing moment, the fairy's face became more and more tight with her anger, and once the young one had darted away, she reached out a tiny little wand to point toward the princess. She uttered a few murmured words, and then with a flick of her wrist, she turned the princess into...
1.title: Her First Mistake

11.content:
Estelle felt a shivering sweep through her body and she closed her eyes for a moment. Opening them again she knew something big had happened. When she saw the green color of her hands she wanted to scream, but a loud croak came out!

Estelle hopped backwards and thought Good grief! I'm hopping! And my feet are gigantic! I'm a frog!

The fairy who had changed Estelle into a frog stepped out from behind her tree and laughed. "That will teach you to hurt the little people."

"I didn't hurt anyone!" Estelle croaked. Then remembered. "Oh, you mean that annoying little fairy? It was HER fault for getting all up in my face like that! Surely you can understand that?"

"Pshaw!" said the older fairy. "Us fairies stick together and we protect our young. If you are going to be a princess in a fantasy kingdom then you should read and understand the rules and regulations regarding fairies, their powers, and the respect due to them."

"Zheesh!" Estelle said. "Are you some kind of fairy lawyer?"

"That's a good idea," Estelle said. "Let's take your case before the fairy court. I wonder what they will sentence you to? Probably worse than being a frog."

"What's worse than that?" Estelle sputtered. "Yes! I want my day in court!"
11.title: Croak!

111.content:
"Order in the court! Here come de judge!" squeaked a mouse.

The judge was a large bullfrog named Ernesto Boogales. Estelle thought the judge being a frog bode well for her case, or did it? Perhaps Judge Boogales considered being turned into frog a very desirable thing. He might not like Estelle complaining about it.

"Your honor," Estelle said. "This fairy turned me into frog for no good reason. I protest!"

"I had a good reason, your honor," said the fairy. "She insulted my daughter."

Everyone in the courtroom gasped and Estelle felt her heart sink. It was obvious everyone was on the side of the fairies.

Judge Boogales looked inquiringly at Estelle. "Is that true?"

"I only asked her to leave me alone, your honor."

"Your exact words, please."

The fairy spoke up. "She said go away, you are not worth my time."

Again everyone in the courtroom gasped.

"And did your daughter say or do anything to elicit such a response?"

The fairy looked around the courtroom before answering. "My daughter pointed at this... monster and said you are pretty."

All eyes turned toward Estelle and they were not happy, loving eyes. They were pitchfork-carrying, torch-burning eyes.
111.title: Estelle's Day In Court

1111.content:
"Your, honor," said Estelle to the frog judge, Ernesto Boogales. "I was having a bad morning. I woke up late and missed my breakfast and I was feeling very out of sorts. When I sat down to try to compose myself, this little fairy brat started tugging on my ears and generally making a nuisance of herself. It's true she said I was pretty but it's also true she did annoying things. So I gently, very gently, brushed her away from me."

"Tell me, Miss Estelle," said Judge Boogales. "How do you feel about being turned into a frog?"

Estelle got ready to cut loose with some vile language about how awful it was, but stopped herself just in time. "It's... it's quite an honor, your honor. Imagine little old me becoming a FROG!"

Here she batted her eyelashes in a very pleasing way. The judge smiled at her.

"Yes," continued Estelle, "I suppose that's the only GOOD thing about this incident is that I get to experience first hand what it feels like to be a frog. Oh, it's so delightful!"

More eyelash batting. "But your honor, my dear old mother will be missing me, and although I would want to remain a frog forever if I could, I know she is one of those awful people who dislike frogs. Do you know what I mean, your honor?"

Judge Boogales nodded in agreement.

"So for her sake, and also because there was NOT justification for anything this fairy has done, I beg you establish my innocence so I can be a princess again. Thank you." She curtsied deeply.

The judge banged his gavel. "I think it's clear what my decision must be..."

-- Estelle was breathless with how quickly he was deciding --

"...and my decision is that you are:
1111.title: The Judge Judges

11111.content:
"Guilty!" The judge declared.

Estelle hopped on the spot.

"What?!" She tried to say more, but croaked in outrage. "But this can't be! I want to be - I mean my mother wants me to be human!"

"Miss Estelle, you do not think I have been a judge for a very long time. You do not think I swallowed that hogwash you just gave me, do you?"

Estelle blinked. That routine had always worked on her parents!

"But... but..." She couldn't put the words together. To add insult to injury, she could see the fairies across the court looking at her smugly, obviously immensely pleased at her suffering.

Estelle bristled. If she still had teeth she would be gnashing them together.

"You can't do this to me! I'm a Princess!"

"We can and we have. You'll find your royal title has no bearing in our kingdom."

"How long will you leave me like this?!"

"Until you learn to respect those smaller than yourself."

114.content:
“Estelle,” called her personal servant.

“I’m here,” croaked the princess. She hopped over to where she could see the servant but the servant didn’t notice the frog.

The servant didn’t understand where the princess has gotten off too.

Estelle watched as her kind, faithful servant returned indoors and shut the door behind her.

“Wait,” called Estelle, “I’m here; oh, don’t shut me out.”

She hopped up to the top step and just set for a while in the warm sun.

She suddenly opened her mouth and stuck out her tongue as a huge fly flitted by. It surprised her so much and went down her throat so fast that she hardly realized what had just happened. The fly filled the empty spot in her stomach. She felt better.

The fairy came by before she moved from the steps and told her that the trial would be held later that day. “Make sure you are there if you want to be heard by the Judge.”

She could hardly wait for the trial time to come. She wanted to sleep in her cozy bed tonight.

She hopped along the palace hedge line at the base of its outside walls, in search of another morsel of food.

As she hopped she plunged down a deep hole created by an underground stream, and the rain water as it rushed along a gorged out path.

The fairy brought charges against the princess. But, since the princess never showed up for the trial the Judge had to rule in the fairies favor. The Princess would remain a frog until she learned a very important lesson.

The princess was lost, everyone thought she had run away because of the bad temper she had been in that morning.

The fairy even worried Estelle might be in trouble, so she looked into her crystal ball and saw the forlorn princess in what appeared to be an underground cave.

The fairy began her search; she visited every place she could remember that resembled an underground dwelling. But she came up empty handed. Then the fairy had an idea…
114.title: An Unfortunate Coincidence

115.content:
"Who????" Who's that peculiar looking scary thing? The question echoed across the room as Estelle was produced in front of the judge.

Estelle looked up in awe. Never in her wildest dreams could she imagine such a handsome little fairy. Unlike the one she had met previously, this one had a charming face, with deep, expressive eyes. His wings were very thin, pointed at the ends. He had a clear, flawless voice. A glittering crown made him even more attractive. He held a tiny wand in one hand, the other rested on his knee.

"Your honor, I found this pestering human, without a proper invitation. I have turned her into this scary creature. Now what to do with her?" The older fairy questioned.
115.title: Now What?!

12.content:
. . . a talking piglet. The older fairy had turned the princess into a talking piglet!

Suddenly, the princess noticed that her clothing really was not fitting right. "What on earth?" she thought as she tried to tug on her sleeve . . . and to her shock instead of her delicate little hand with her delicate pink nail polish . . . there seemed to be a small pig's foot sticking out of her sleeve!

Estelle pulled back with astonishment . . . and the little pig foot pulled back, too.

"What was happening?" she thought. "I think that I will go back inside." she said to herself, "I don't feel well." Estelle started to get up but instead of standing, she fell off the bench and landed in a heap of skirt and legs. When she did finally manage to get to her feet she was on four feet instead of two . . . and two of the four were quite tangled in the fabric from her skirt . . . which was getting quite soiled.

Estelle felt another tug on her ear. She turned and flitting around her snout . . . yes, her snout . . . by now Estelle realized that however it had happened, she had turned into a little pig!

How could that be. Those things only happen in fairytales. Fairytales! That was it. That tiny girl with blue hair, purple eyes, pink skin and wings was a fairy.

Estelle's little pig eyes flashed, "YOU did this to me!" She glared at the trembling ball of wings and blue hair.
12.title: a talking piglet.

Estelle tried with all her might to swing at the little fairy but because she was not a piglet she couldn't reach her. Her beautiful clothing was getting ruined because her little pig feet were crushing the expensive material into the dirt beneath her feet.

The princess was getting more and more angry. She didn't like being a pig. Not only that she couldn't express her feeling because all she could do was squeal.

The older fairy felt a little story for the princess. So she....

122.content:
The older fairy flew in front of Estelle's porky face and tapped the princess' snout with her golden wand. Sparks of pink light flew from the wand. The sparks matched the color of Estelle's new skin.

"It was I who transformed you, you spoiled brat!" the older fairy growled. Estelle batted at her with a hoof and squealed with rage.

"Undo this now, you wench!" Estelle cried. She oinked and squealed more as she tried to stand upright. It was impossible with her new piglet's body. She settled onto all fours. Her dress was getting filthier by the moment.

"You had no reason to be so rude to the young fairy," the older fairy said. "She is a respected member of my fairy kingdom."

"I will have you imprisoned for this, you old hag!" Estelle declared. She pawed at the ground with her tiny hooves. How would she turn back into a human?

"I am Queen Giana of Fairygarr," the older fairy said. "My kingdom could also wage war on your human kingdom if I'm jailed."

"Just turn me back into a human. We'll work it all out then," Estelle commanded.

"I can do it myself, but you must apologize to Calista, the young fairy," Queen Giana said. Estelle shook her head. Her pink ears twitched back and forth.

"Very well, then you'll have to find a sorcerer to turn you back to your former miserable self," Queen Giana said. Estelle grunted. Sorcerers were difficult to find today since magic had been outlawed.

What should Estelle do?
122.title: Then Estelle sees the older fairy.

1221.content:
Estelle clenched her teeth. She had half a mind to give these fairies a piece of her mind and hunt for a sorcerer. But if she did that, she could be stuck like this for hours, if not days.

"Fine, I am sorry, fairy." Estelle huffed.

Queen Giana folded her arms.

"Her name is Calista! Do you even know why you are apolgizing?"

"Sorry.. Calista. And.. because I was rude?"

Giana stared Estelle down, her eyes boring into her. Estelle shock in discomfort.

"Yes, but more than that, you hurt her and treated her the way you humans would treat a bug to be carelessly swatted aside. Are you truly sorry for what you did?"

"Yes of course!" Estelle tried to use her sweetest voice, the one she used when she needled her parents. "Please change me back!"

"You are not sorry. Maybe if we leave you like this you will understand. Come on Calista, lets go." Giana gently scooped up the young fairy and turned to leave.

"Wait!"

13.content:
"We'll just see how well you like being a fairy then. Treat one of us like that.... Silly human girl!" the older fairy muttered as she watched the transformation with an air of satisfaction. "That will teach her..."

The princess, meanwhile, felt very strange all of a sudden, and was beginning to think she ought to go back to bed. Was she sick? Was that why everything seemed to make her irritable today? She started to her feet when she felt a strange tingling at the base of her neck that branched along her limbs as it traveled downwards. What was wrong with her?

The princess pinched her arm softly and watched as it began shrinking. Her other arm, and soon the rest of her body, began to do so as well. Then her skin began to turn an iridescent orange color, that softly glowed. She felt wings protrude from the middle of her back. They were full, and thin, and silvery.

Oh dear! What shall I do now. Mother and everyone else will be missing me shortly, thought the princess. But it didn't do her any good to think these things. She was stuck as a little fairy- and she could do nothing about it.

The princess sat down with a huff on top of a flower, but then concluded she might as well go exploring and make good use of her new wings. So with that thought the princess stood up, and leaped of of the flower.

The ground came rushing up at her quickly and she began flapping her thin wings to slow it down. She landed roughly and rolled a short distance. When she looked up she saw...

131.content:
The princess fairy gasped for breath, which had been knocked out of her by the near fatal fall. There prowling over her body was a huge beast that looked strangely enough like her cat, Sir Purrduke.

She felt relieved knowing he was a friendly cat. She knew though how he loved to play with anything that moved. She was aware of the danger she was in.

Instead of trying to escape to safer ground she froze in place. Finally Sir Purrduke moved on, disinterested.

“Whew! That was a close one. Next time I try a flight I better be in more control.”

She wondered if she should find her mother the Queen, or her personal servant Lydia, and tell them what had happened to her. But she was sure they wouldn’t believe her since there was a law against believing anything a fairy said to a member of the royal family. Safety came first.

She also knew another fairy wouldn’t listen to her because their law forbade them from fraternizing with fairies of a different kind.

“What am I to do; is there no one to talk to or any friend I can confide in?”

Feeling lonely and ashamed of this morning’s tirade, Estelle decided to search the grounds for a friendly face. People liked to collect fairies, and fairies, for this reason, didn’t go around humans very often, on purpose that is.

This time when she tried her wings she had the control she needed. She felt grateful to the angry fairy for giving her a fairy body; her punishment could have been so much worse. Her biggest complaint was the color the fairy had chosen. She figured that somehow the fairy had heard it was not her favorite color and wanted to further humiliate her.

As she flew along a swift enemy flew stealthily toward her…
131.title: A cat

1311.content:
Estelle could fly quite well now, although the odd gust of wind could send her spinning upwards or downwards until she could steady herself again. She flew onward, trying to find the Queen, but as she flew she wondered how she would explain herself.

She flew on, absorbed in her thoughts, almost unaware of her surroundings. A sudden flash of brown filtered through her mind and she turned, but felt a sharp pain in her side... and she felt into a daze.

Coming round, Estelle realised in horror she was being carried in the strong beak of a female robin!

"How can I be so unlucky?" she cried to herself,

"Please, Mrs Robin, don't eat me, I am lost and all alone, and I need to find my mother."

The robin's reply was muffled, but Estelle could just make out the words,

"My children are hungry, and I must feed them."

"Wait, I can get you much more delicious food than I !" Estelle cried,

"I can find you all the best worms and beetles, and flies."

The robin swerved in mind air and dropped Estelle onto a branch.

"Quickly, tell me how, or I'll eat you and feed you to my children."

The spider hung there from its huge web, glistening in the sunlight. She had just missed landing in it and realized just how close she came to being its breakfast! She shuddered at the thought and then noticed the spider threading itself closer. The spider swung back up its thread in shock and screeched. "Ouch! What was that for? I do not eat fairies, and am not fond of orange either. The Queen of the Fae would destroy my my children if I dared. She has the most unruly orange hair and is quite fearsome. I thought for a moment you might be her kin but you smell very strange and those words ..." the spider broke off as..

1323.content:
"Spider!" her voice shrilled as she glared at the eight legged insect, wand at the ready. "I saw you eating a fairy."

"No ma'am, not me," the spider shook it's head, backing away instinctively.

The Queen of the Fae peered around his huge, brown body at his web. She saw that his web was empty, glistening in the sunlight. "Very well," she nodded once, curtly. It seemed that she realised just then that there was another fairy right beside her. She spun quickly to face this newcomer.

"And you are?" she asked, her voice haughty.

"I am...I'm..."

"Don't dawdle," she yelled. "Who are you?"

"I'm the Princess," she told the Queen truthfully.

"Princess, ha! You are no more a princess than this spider is," the Queen gestured towards the spider who had made his way back to his home and was spinning more thread.

"But Queen, I am. I was sitting in the garden when a fairy changed me into this," she gestured to her new body.


"I see," said the Queen.. She began stroking her chin as if deep in thought. "And who was this fairy who changed you?"

"I have no idea," the Princess shook her head. "I didn't even know fairies existed until now."

"What? the Queen screeched, shocking. "How silly can you be, girl?"

The Princess blushed.

"Well, what are we to do now?" the Queen asked, talking to herself.

"I'd very much like to be a girl again," the Princess said truthfully.

"You don't want to be a fairy?"

"Well..."

"Come with me," the Queen said out of the blue. She grabbed the Princesses hand and they began to fly together to...
1323.title: the Queen of Fae appeared

133.content:
A fairy which was passing by overhead, caught sight of her and approached her. His skin was deep blue. He had a shock of light blue hair and he seemed curious.

"Hi, there," he said, after he landed in front of her, "Are you alright?"

He held out his hand. The princess could not help blushing because the fairy was quite handsome. Her cheeks turned a crimson hue, when she reached for his hand. He helped her to her feet.

"Well, not really..." she managed to say, her eyes darting here and there in her sudden shyness.

"What's the matter?" he asked, "Are you lost?"

"Yes," she replied, feeling happy about his concern.

"Ah, no wonder I've not seen you around here before. What's your name? I'm William".

"Everyone calls me Princess," she said.

Oh, that's a new kind of name. Do you come from a kingdom where you are a princess?" he asked her.

This question brought her back into the reality of the situation. The thoughts of her mother, her father, the palace and comforts came rushing to her, along with the thought that she may not be able to return to her original state again.

"You miss home, don't you?" said William, noticing her stricken face, "Come with me. I will take you to our Fairy Queen at the Akasia, which is where she meets all fairies of our tribe. Maybe she'll know what to do".

But the princess was suddenly overcome by fear and helplessness that she broke down crying. William tried to console her but no avail.

"Maybe you would like to see our pond. It is beautiful and you will surely feel better if you spend some time there," he said.

So where will the princess go?
133.title: A handsom blue fairy named William

the sunlight sparkling through the mist of the water fountain. The light formed a barely perceptible rainbow. The princess thought to herself wondering why she had never noticed the rainbow before. Was it always there? She flew toward the fountain and a felt the tug of her wings carrying her through the air. As she drew closer to the fountain, the air felt different. It felt thicker somehow and she had to work harder to fly. When she arrived, she sat on the edge of the middle tier basin of the fountain. She dipped her fairy feet into the water and looked up to the sky through the mist of the splashing water. The vapors continued to form that almost visible rainbow. It dazzled her eyes and she felt a warm joy. She giggled at the wonder of it all, then turn her gaze down toward her feet. She kicked the water, making waves ripple across the basin. When she stopped kicking, she noticed her reflection in the water. Her face appeared distorted at first until the ripples decreased and the water was smooth enough to see clearly her face. She leaned forward and looked deeply into her own eyes. "Am I beautiful?" She spoke the words out loud in a high pitched tone that only a fairy's voice can make. She lifted her hand and touched her cheek with her finger tips. As she stared, she noticed that the warm feeling of joy was gone. Instead she felt cold. Tears formed in her eyes and one teardrop fell to the water causing more ripples. Her reflection was distorted again.

"I've been horrible. I must find that fairy and apologize!"

She stood up and leapt off the fountain. Her wings carried her the center of the garden. Her eyes darted back and forth, desperate to find the other fairy. She noticed a pinkish glow in a shadow under the shrubs in a corner of the garden. She flew toward it and there she found...
135.title: Her reflection

1351.content:
“I’m sorry!” The princess shouted the words as she darted toward the child fairy. Dust wafted into the air as she landed next to the whimpering child. She placed her arms and wings around the child and said, “There, there, don’t cry. I am so sorry to have treated you so badly.”

“You mean you are not so mean after all,” the child fairy replied with a slight smile. She uncurled her body from her cowering ball shape and the two held hands as they sat on the ground across from each other with their legs crossed.

“You don’t need to be sad just because I shooed you away. I was in a selfish mood. It was not your fault,” said the princess.

“But it is my fault! You see, I am the fairy responsible for making you happy. I am the reason you were in such a bad mood this morning. I was supposed to be there when you awoke… but I wasn’t… I was…,” the child fairy let go of the princess’ hands and stared at the ground, stirring the dirt with her fingers.

“Why? Why weren’t you there?” The princess asked intrepidly. The child fairy looked glum. Her wings drooped down and even her pig-tails seemed less happy.

The child fairy looked up again, stared deeply into the princess’ eyes and said, “Last night as you slept, it was my turn to bring you happy dreams. I searched the garden for the most beautiful dew drop, for dew drops are one of the main ingredients in dreams, but the fountain was turned off. When I saw the reflection of the moon and the stars in the basin of the fountain, I turned and looked up to sky. The moon was so clear and bright, I felt as if I could reach out and touch it. I flew up to the sky, higher than high, reaching for that untouchable beauty, but the higher I flew, the colder I felt. Still, I kept trying, I kept flying, higher and higher until a sudden wind blew a set of clouds over me. At first I thought the clouds were beautiful too, so I paused for moment. As the clouds washed over me, I got lost. It was cold and wet. I no longer knew which way was up or down.”

The princess sat captivated by the story, hanging on every word. She reached for the child fairy’s hands and they resumed holding hands as the child fairy continued her tale.

“The clouds grew darker and darker until there was no moonlight at all. I panicked, for moonlight is another important ingredient for dreams, especially happy dreams. I was so cold that I started to shiver. I held my wings close, they wrapped around my body for warmth and I started to fall to the ground. I plummeted through clouds for what seemed like an eternity. When the ground finally appeared I opened my wings and got caught on a wind that carried me far away. When I finally landed, I was so tired that I lay down on a rock next to a stream. The babbling brook swiftly put me to sleep.”

The child fairy paused for a moment, then started again. “I awoke to the Song of Dawn. The babbling brook sings it so well. It was beautiful, but I had no time to listen. The sun was already creeping over the horizon and I had only a short time now to reach you and bring you your dreams. I tried to fly, but my wings were still tired from my journey toward the moon, so I had to run on the ground. By the time I got to your bedroom, you were already awake.”

The child fairy started to cry again. The princess reached out and held her in a hug. The princess said, “It’s alright. I forgive you. It wasn’t your fault. I think the moon is beautiful too.”

The child fairy trembled and cried for a few moments and finally said, “Thank you. Thank you for being so forgiving. I promise, I will never again fail to bring you your dreams.”

The princess looked at the child fairy and said, “I just realized that you probably know me as Estelle, but I don’t know your name. Call me Stella.”

The child fairy smiled the most beautiful smile. Her pink skin seemed to sparkle as it glowed. “My name is Amethyst. You can call me Thysta.”

The sun was warming the garden now. A slight breeze swept through garden and lifted a large maple leaf that was resting next to the girls. The two girls were surprised when they found hiding under the leaf was…
1351.title: the child fairy curled up in a ball weeping.

13513.content:
“Oh, no! Not again! Maximillian, you really must be more careful.” Thysta got up and walked over to the butterfly. Its blue wings shimmered with iridescence. It struggled to turn toward Thysta.

“My wing, my wing, it is the thing. With one swift stroke, it was so broke. My precious wing, this precious thing, can you fix my precious wing?” The butterfly spoke in melody.

Thysta reached out her hand to the torn wing and much to Stella’s surprise, Thysta’s fingertips began to glow with a bright yellow light. The light grew brighter and brighter until a flash of light briefly blinded Stella. When Stella opened her eyes, she found that the torn wing had been repaired.

“You healed him!” Stella spoke in shock.

“Of course, all fairies have healing powers. That is one of our many tasks. Estelle, this is Maximillian. Max, this is Stella.” Thysta curtsied as she introduced them.

Max stood up straight on his rear legs, stretched his wings out into the air, as if to show them off to her, then bowed, tucking his right wing forward underneath his body with a flourish. “Pleasure is mine, to meet of thine, a girl so fine, and so divine.”

“Oh, Max, you’re such a flatterer,” said Thysta.

“Pleasure,” said Stella as she returned his bow with a curtsy. “Tell me, Max, do you always speak in rhyme?”

“Well, always is, as always was, this is a quiz, for what Max does. He speaks in rhyme, now all the time, but for young Max, it was not rhyme,” Max again replied in melody.

“Oh, please don’t get him started on recounting his youth!” Thysta interrupted. “Yes, Max, we know, when you were young you would sing.” Thysta tugged on Stella’s arm. “Come on, time to go.”

The two girls started to flutter into the air. Max slowly followed, saying, “But wait, there’s more, there’s so much more. Just wait, there’s more, to butterfly lore.”

Stella turned her head back to look at Max, but Thysta hastened their flight and said, “No, no. That’s enough butterfly lore for now. Goodbye Max. Goodbye.”

Stella said goodbye as well and looked at Thysta with a questioning look. “Why didn’t you let him tell his story?”

Thysta got them flying in a direction away from Max and replied, “You know, Stella, I love the butterflies, their beautiful wings with brilliant colors and patterns, but there are only so many hours in a day.” She glanced at the sun. “Max is a wonderful butterfly, but once he starts a story, it just never ends. And we need to find a way to get you back to being a princess again.”

“How can we do that? I don’t even know how I got here,” Stella replied.

“Well, here’s the thing. Healing and creating happy dreams are not the only things that fairies can do. Sometimes, they, well…” Thysta stammered.

“What? What else do they do?” Stella asked.

“Well, sometimes they get angry… and do things that… are not kind.”

“So, you’re saying I angered a fairy when I shooed you away?”

“Yes,” Thysta answered. She looked a little bit sad.

“But, who was it? Was it you?”

“No, it wasn’t me.”

“Then who?”

“I’m not sure. But if we do not find the fairy and convince her to reverse the spell before dawn tomorrow, then you will be forever…”
13513.title: An Injured Butterfly

135132.content:
“What? What will I forever be if we don’t find her?” Stella asked with a concerned looked on her face. She reached out to Thysta. She held Thysta’s hands and looked into her eyes. Thysta’s eyes were a deeper purple now. It was a dark purple, an almost black purple.

“You see, there is more to this spell than just you becoming a fairy. Fairies aren’t born. Fairies were children once. All of us were children. We were children who needed some help finding our kindness. Those of us who found it before the following dawn were allowed a choice. We could choose to remain as fairies or return to a mortal life. With either choice, we must also promise to practice kindness every day.” Thysta paused and looked off into the distance.

Stella thought for a moment. She thought about kindness. She thought about her own choices and how she had treated everyone that she knew. She wondered which she would choose: the endless days of a fairy or the numbered days of a human life. One question remained unanswered.

“What about those who do not find their kindness before the dawn?”

Thysta replied, “They do not have a choice. They return to being the children that they were, only they never know kindness ever again. They spend their entire lives with cold hearts and closed minds. They never again know wonder or beauty or joy. They never find solace in any corner of the world, not in any garden, not in any flower, not even in a rainbow.”

Stella was mortified. She shivered at the thought of never again seeing beauty in the garden flowers.

“We must find her, this fairy, and prove to her that I can be kind, that I will be kind.” Stella shivered again. “I promise I will be kind. Please help me find her! Where should we look first?”

Thysta straightened her back and arched her wings. Her eyes brightened to a brilliant, glowing purple. “I believe you. You do have kindness in you. Come. Let’s start with the caterpillars.”

With renewed hope, Stella followed Thysta to the milkweed outside the garden.

“I should warn you, while the caterpillars have wisdom and they know just about everything going on in the garden, they are a little,” Stella rolled her eyes, “…difficult to talk to.”

When they arrived at the milkweed meadow, Thysta heard music. It was a choir of singers each singing their own song. Once in a while, a small group would collaborate and sing the same song. The harmonies would find new notes and then one caterpillar after another would drift off to a new song. It was a cacophony of a cappella chaos.

Thysta touched Stella on the wrist to signal her to stand back. Stella waited and watched as Thysta cleared her throat.

“Hello, my friends, my sweet, beautiful singers. How are you today?”

Thysta’s voice varied through a range of notes as she tried to match the current song of the closest caterpillar.

“Why, sweet Thysta, sweet Amythysta, we are good today. And it is, we see, that you have brought us a child, a child that lost her way.” The caterpillar rose up on its hind body and its voice reverberated with operatic volume.

Thysta replied, “Oh good, you know what we seek, we seek what can be true. We seek to find the good in all, we seek some help from you.”

Other caterpillars took notice of Thysta’s voice. She sang with the soft notes of a piano. The notes had a calming effect on Stella, who now just watched and listened to the musical exchange.

The other caterpillars provided a chorus to the response from the closer caterpillar who switched from an opera to a doo-wop tempo.

“Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
We know your need.

Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
The one you seek.

She was mad,
She was sad,
Now she hides,
Where you had,

Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
We know your need.

Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
The one you seek.

Made her glad,
Such a cad,
Froggy knows
Lilly pad.

Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
We know your need.

Sweet Thysta, Thysta,
The one you seek.”

“Oh, thank you so much,” Thysta replied. “You are wonderful! Keep singing.”

The caterpillars kept singing as Thysta and Stella flew off to the koi pond.

When they arrived at the koi pond, they found the…
135132.title: Cold-Hearted

1351323.content:
Large round leaves wobbled and bounced on the surface of the water as a slight breeze formed ripples across the tiny pond. The pond was tiny but deep. The water was dark. There was no seeing the fish below. Stella knew the only way to attract them to the surface was to toss a few bread crumbs at the spaces between the lily pads. She and Thysta landed on a nearby rock and sat down to rest their wings.

At the center of the pond was the only lily flower in bloom. The pink petals provided a great contrast to the green lily pads and dark water. As Thysta and Stella sat scanning the pond for any sign of the older fairy, two large eyes popped up from just beneath the surface of the dark water.

“Hello Mister Frog,” Thysta spoke up.

The frog climbed up on a lily pad and returned the greeting, “Hello Thysta.” The voice had a deep, booming sound to it.

“Have you seen Thunkadunk? The caterpillars said that she may be able to help us.”

Frog replied, “Are you going to introduce me to your friend first?”

“Oh, yes, how rude of me. Mister Frog, this is Stella. Stella, this is Mister Frog.”

Stella stood up and curtsied, then sat back down. “Pleasure to meet you Mister Frog.”

“And it is a pleasure to meet you, young Princess Estelle. It seems that shrinking to the size of a fairy has helped you to do some growing up today. Don’t you agree?”

“Do you know me, sir?”

“Of course I know you. I have watched you visit the pond many times. You have a special way of smiling when you feed my friends, the fish. Lately, that smile has turned to a frown. Do you think you could smile again?”

Stella was not sure how to feel. She felt a rush of emotions, from shyness to awkwardness to a flattered blush. She glanced down at her feet and then looked up with her eyes. She touched her cheeks with her hands and then smiled.

“That is the smile I was hoping for. That is the smile of kindness and wonder. Now, I think you might have a question for me.”

“Yes, sir. We are looking for the fairy that transformed me to this size. I must apologize to her, for my behavior. Do you know where she is?”

“I do. And what will you say to her when you find her?”

“I will tell her how awful I was and how much I regret it. I know now that I was being selfish and unkind. I never should have swatted at Thysta when she was only trying to help me. I never should have been so demanding of the house staff. They do everything for me and all they ask in return is a bit of kindness. I must tell her these things for I truly feel them now. My eyes have been opened to a beauty that I never knew was there.”

The pink flower at the center of the pond began to glow. A bright pink light rose up out of its center and hovered above the pond. When the light diminished, there hovered the older fairy.

“I accept your apology,” the older fairy said to Stella.

Both Stella and Thysta stood up and bowed before the older fairy.

“Thank you! Oh thank you so much!” Stella said.

“You have learned your lesson. Now that you know of our world, you have a choice to make. You may choose the manner in which you will spread kindness to the world. Will it be as a fairy, or as a human being?”

All eyes watched as Stella pondered the consequences or her choices. As a fairy, she could be kind forever to countless people, but as a human being, she could apologize to those whom she has wronged with her selfishness.

“I wish to be a child again,” she spoke with great resolve.

“As you wish.”

The older fairy raised her hands to the sky. Stella looked up and squinted as her gaze crossed the sun. She felt herself being lifted into the air, spinning and turning with her eyes closed. She became dizzy and soon passed out.

When she awoke, she found herself lying on the bench in the center of the garden being shaken awake by the cook. She was her normal child size again.

“You missed breakfast,” the cook said to her while handing her a small bowl of porridge with strawberries, blueberries and cinnamon.

“Oh thank you! It is so thoughtful of you to remember me.” Stella stood up and hugged the cook almost knocking over the bowl of porridge.

“You’re welcome! My, you are in a good mood today. I’ll leave you to your breakfast.”

“Please stay and sit with me. Let’s watch the water spray from the fountain together. If you look at just the right angle, you might see a rainbow.”

The cook sat down and together they watched the water, they listened to the breeze shuffling the leaves in the trees, and Stella could almost hear some distant singing.

Epilogue

“The outcome was good, but do you not think that you may have over-reacted when you turned her into a fairy?” said Mister Frog to Thunkadunk.

“Of course I over-reacted! My name is Thunkadunk! What kind of a name is that for a fairy? I over-react to everything,” said the older fairy to Mister Frog.

Just then, a large orange and white koi fish breached the surface of the pond and Thunkadunk was splashed in the face with water.

“Hey! How dare you? I’ll show you what happens to fish who splash water at me.”

Mister Frog blinked his eyes and settled into a comfortable spot, hoping Stella might visit today.

The End.

"I'm not allowed," Susanna murmured, hanging her head.

"I'm a Princess! You can't deny me anything," Estelle exclaimed. "Now change me back, or get thrown in the moat," she demanded.

Susanna shuddered. The Fairy Discipline Council had temporarily revoked her spellcasting permit for carelessness. Now she had lost control. Her future appeared bleak: a toss in the moat, another visit to the council, and public humiliation.

Estelle scowled. " I don't expect to wait, fairy. People wait for me."

"Y-yes, Princess," Susanna stammered. " But I still can't. I had only one spell left, and I just used it." And that spell was for emergencies. Hoo boy. She cringed." I'm out of spells, Your Highness, and I can't get more. I'm sorry."

"Sorry! What good is that?" Estelle shrieked. " I'm a hamster, you dingbat! So now," Estelle snarled, " what will you do?"

info.brief_description: This is a story about a rather misguided princess, and a very upset fairy.
info.description:
A misguided princess finds herself interacting with an easily irritated fairy, which creates some rather disastrous results! While I will begin the story in the first chapter, there are a few requests I'd like to make before we go in, if you are wanting to contribute to this story:

1. Please don't kill off everyone. Without characters, there is no story. While it may eventually make sense for a character to die, let's not just kill everyone off with machine guns for no reason, mmm?

2. Each direction might take a different set of characters. And that is fine! The beauty of an interactive story is that you can choose the way you'd like it to go, and then add in things you'd like to see if it hasn't been written yet.

3. Let's keep to the setting, please. This one will be in a fantasy setting with princesses, kings, carriages, servants, and other things. (Yes, I know I'm a grown woman, but I think these can be amusing for everyone. See the overall positive opinions about "The Princess Bride" for proof that these sorts of settings CAN be amusing for all ages.)

4. There's an ASR rating - I'd like to keep it that way. Anything that would pertain to a higher rating shouldn't be added. And if it is believed that it makes sense in the story, feel free to email me about your idea! I'll take a glance.


Alrighty! Let's get ourselves started!
